newsitem.title: USA: Alaska Air orders 12 Boeing 737-400 aircraft.
newsitem.headline: Alaska Air orders 12 Boeing 737-400 aircraft.

text.p: Alaska Air Group Inc said it has ordered 12 Boeing Co 737-400 aircraft with the option to acquire up to 12 more.
The company said the value of the order, based on the manufacturer's list price, is about $540 million.
Alaska said the delivery of the 12 new 737-400s will be phased in over the next three years, with the first new plane scheduled to enter the fleet in June 1997.

The company said the new planes will replace 12 older McDonnell Douglas Corp MD-80s. Under provisions of the deal, Alaska may substitute some or all of its options for the newest derivatives of the Boeing 737 -- the 737-600, 700 and 800 aircraft.

"This order moves us one step closer toward fleet simplification without relinquishing our flexibility regarding future fleet decisions," said John Kelly, chairman and chief executive. "Moreover, we'll be replacing aircraft on a one-for-one basis, making the youngest fleet of any major carrier in the U.S. that much younger."
Alaska's current fleet is 7.5 years old.
